The hand of time has rung the parting knell,</br>The busy, bustling scene at length is o'er;</br>Within these walls, dull peace and silence dwell,</br>These walls, where noise and nonsense reign'd before.
No swelling sounds my list'ning ear approach,</br>No voices now in fine confusion rise,</br>Save the rough rattle of the passing coach,</br>Or piercing melody of Dublin Cries;
Save that from yonder church's trembling tower</br>The joyous bells their peals obstreperous ring,</br>To celebrate the fall of Lawless Power,</br>The Gaul returning to his rightful King.
Beneath this cobweb'd roof, and on this floor,</br>Where not a mortal but myself now stands,</br>How oft' was heard the BOARD'S tumultuous roar,</br>The clamorous plaudit, and the clap of hands?
The hope which bade DISUNION'S friends rejoice,</br>The envied honour of OUR SPEAKER'S chair,</br>The Doctor's twang, the Lawyers brazen voice,</br>No more shall rouse them from their deep despair.
For them no more the midnight Lamps shall burn,</br>Or titled Chairmen on their labours smile;</br>Nor Secretary make his year's return</br>Of tenpennies collected through the Isle.
Oft did the statute to their purpose bend,</br>The neck of law oft felt their sturdy stroke;</br>How many a brave petition here was penn'd,</br>How many a resolution made — and broke!
Let not grave Wisdom mock their shallow views,</br>Their dreams of Empire, their new Rights of Man;</br>Nor pride of British Senators refuse</br>Some credit to the bold but luckless plan.
The happiest system fram'd by mortals skill,</br>The highest fabric vast ambition rears,</br>Can but its short and destin'd course fulfil,</br>Relentless Time no human structure spares.
Perhaps in this deserted room was seen</br>Some genius form'd on Fame's bright wing to soar,</br>Had times and changes more propitious been,</br>Had revolution throve on Ireland's shore.
But niggard Fortune, to their merits blind,</br>Refus'd the sanction of her fostering aid,</br>To petty feuds their noble rage confin'd,</br>And o'er their glories cast an envious shade.
Full many a vein of Copper's stubborn ore</br>The rugged mountain's unpierc'd bosom fills,</br>Full many a string of Florin's valued store</br>Spreads all unnoticed on the northern hills.
Mayhap, 'midst Chiefs, whose too contracted bound</br>Forbade them Faction's trespass to exceed,</br>Some unfledg'd Buonaparte might be found,</br>Some Cromwell with the will, but not the deed.
O'er spurn'd authorities to hold command,</br>The subjects sworn allegiance to despise,</br>To mar the scheme by ancient Wisdom plann'd,</br>They greatly aided — but Fate withheld the prize.
Yet not unfruitful was the project bold</br>To stripling Lawyers feath'ring here their nest,</br>Who saw the swelling bag its briefs scarce hold,</br>The bag where moths once found untroubled rest.
Through what strange scenes and changes all things pass,</br>In this uncertain sublunary sphere!</br>Perhaps, where ranted champions of the Mass,</br>Some raving Methodist may split the ear!
Perhaps the buskin'd hero here may tread,</br>To act like us his temporary part;</br>Some grave Professor's lectures may be read,</br>Or crowds admire some newer Juggler's art!
Such is the changeful state of all below,</br>And we must learn to bear the common lot;</br>Yet shall it some consoling hope bestow,</br>To think, tho' dead, we shall not be forgot—
Yes — to my fancy grateful is the task,</br>To paint to future times our fate deplor'd;</br>To think should curious wight hereafter ask,</br>Some hist'ry of the once renowned Board.
How haply some old Dublin cit may say,</br>Oft have we seen them, like a flight of crows,</br>Urging to yon lov'd place their evening way,</br>And, like Macbeth, destroying night's repose.
There, (for tho' young we squeez'd to get a place)</br>How did we wonder at their strength of lungs,</br>The noble fire of every brazen face,</br>The modern Babel and its strife of Tongues.
Forbear fond muse — no further traits disclose,</br>The curtain falls — the Sun descends in fog—</br>They seek in distant wilds unwish'd repose,</br>Macgillicuddy's Reeks, and Allen's Bog.—</br>
